content: I loved studying electronic products when I was in high school. I received my bachelor’s degree from Harbin Engineering University in 2019. During this period, I received excellent grades and numerous awards, includin First prize in the Heilongjiang Provincial Electronic Design Competition for three consecutive years, second prize in the National College Student Electronic Design Competition, second prize (top 10 teams in China) in the TI Cup Analog Invitational Competition (sponsored by the famous American semiconductor company Texas InstrumentsÔºåonly one team per school), Ministry of Industry and Information Technology Scholarship (National defense), etc.. I obtained my master’s degree from Southeast University in 2022. During this period, I mainly conducted research on radio frequency systems and antennas. Responsible for the research and development of many projects, including large satellite phased array antennas and circuit systems, new system radar development, ultra-wideband radio detection system, etc. My master’s thesis won the Excellent Paper of the China Electronics Society (Only about 40 per year in China). At the same time, I also won other awards, such as Rohde & Schwarz Scholarship, Chuangyuan Scholarship, First Prize in Graduate Electronic Design Competition, etc. After graduation, I received many offers, including ZTE Blue Sword Plan, TPlink SSSP (Highest salary for fresh Master graduates), Huawei senior engineer (Level 16, the first senior engineer to join the Shanghai CBG department with a master’s degree). In 2020, I interned at Ericsson in Beijing for 3 months. I was mainly responsible for the design and R&D of base station power amplifiersÔºà600M-1GHzÔºâ. I successfully completed and implemented the design and development of broadband PA in a limited space. In 2021, I interned at Nanjing Purple Mountain Lab for more than half a year, mainly responsible for satellite phased array system antenna design and RF front-end research and development work. I joined Huawei in 2022 and engage in the development of related millimeter wave radars and terminal mobile phones and won some Root Technology Breakthrough Awards. I joined Lund University in Sweden at the end of 2023 and engage in wireless communication related work.
summary: I loved studying electronic products when I was in high school. I received my bachelor’s degree from Harbin Engineering University in 2019. During this period, I received excellent grades and numerous awards, includin First prize in the Heilongjiang Provincial Electronic Design Competition for three consecutive years, second prize in the National College Student Electronic Design Competition, second prize (top 10 teams in China) in the TI Cup Analog Invitational Competition (sponsored by the famous American semiconductor company Texas InstrumentsÔºåonly one team per school), Ministry of Industry and Information Technology Scholarship (National defense), etc.
title: Jiawang Li

content: A highly integrated millimeter-wave radar imaging system based on L-shaped antenna array is proposed and implemented.The system is based on the frequency modulation continuous wave phased array system, and consists of a frequency sweep source, a transmitting and receiving link, and a beamforming antenna with the function of transmitting and receiving switching.The antenna adopts a microstrip antenna, and the unit is designed to have a wide beam pattern, which is convenient for wide-angle scanning during the line array scanning process.When the radar system is working, first use the phase shifter of the transmitting channel in the beamforming chip to deflect the beam at a specific angle, and then the receiving link traverses through scanning N beams to find the target, and the echo data at this time is 1√óN In the form of a matrix, the direction of the transmitting beam is changed until the entire imaging target is searched, and the received intermediate frequency reflects the distance information of the imaging target.With the wide application of millimeter-wave beamforming chips, compared with imaging systems using multi-beam systems, too many radio frequency channels and baseband ADCs are saved, and the overall integration level is improved. While ensuring a certain imaging accuracy , which greatly reduces the imaging cost.
summary: A highly integrated millimeter-wave radar imaging system based on an L-shaped antenna array.
title: L-Shape Highly Integrated Millimeter wave Phased Array Imaging System

summary: (Accepted by iWEM) 2021 IEEE International Workshop on Electromagnetics Applications and Student Innovation Competition
title: Millimeter Wave Filtenna with Compact Size for 5G Applications

content: A wide bandwidth angular scanning phased array antenna array working in 24.25~29.5GHz is proposed.The antenna is based on the mixed mode of monopole antenna and microstrip antenna, adding a symmetrical monopole antenna around the traditional microstrip antenna, extending the previous ¬±45¬∞ scan to ¬±60¬∞.At the same time, in order to achieve miniaturization, on the basis of not affecting the performance of the antenna, the size of the antenna unit is set to 4mm√ó4mm, and the polarization isolation under the same unit can reach 20dB.At the same time, in order to further improve the isolation between units and avoid the occurrence of scanning blind spots, the defect-in-ground (DGS) technology is adopted to effectively remove the scanning blind spots in the band.As a verification, an 8√ó8 scale highly integrated phased array antenna array using beamforming chip phase shifting was designed and tested. The whole board achieves a wide operating bandwidth by laying out two different stacked SICL power splitters. Ensures uniformity of power reaching the chip while also ensuring high isolation between the two polarizations.The entire antenna aperture including the surrounding dummy elements is only 4cm√ó4cm, the measured antenna scanning angle can reach ¬±60¬∞, and it works in the 5G millimeter wave frequency band, which is very suitable for broadband millimeter wave communication systems such as small base stations.
summary: A small dual-polarization phased array system operating at 24.25~29.5GHz for mmWave base stations.
title: Miniaturized Millimeter wave Base Station Platform

summary: (Accepted by GSMM) 2021 13th Global Symposium on Millimeter-Waves & Terahertz (GSMM)
title: Dual polarized Antenna and Array with Filtering Response and Low Cross Polarization for 5G Millimeter Wave Applications

summary: (Accepted by IWS) 2021 IEEE MTT-S International Wireless Symposium (IWS)
title: Millimeter Wave Broadband Circularly Polarized Antenna and Array with Stacked Structure

content: Aiming at the insertion loss problem caused by the filter in the millimeter wave transceiver, a millimeter wave filter antenna and a related phased array antenna design based on a single mode resonator are proposed.The average gain of the simulated antenna is 5.5dBi, and the actual measurement and simulation are in good agreement. The upper sideband suppression of the antenna exceeds 30dB, and the lower sideband suppression exceeds 10dB. The antenna has a steeper cut-off frequency band.Compared with other types of filter antennas, the filter antennas designed in this chapter have a simpler structure, more radiation nulls, relatively fewer stacks and lower cost, higher upper sideband rejection, lower profile, and lower cost. The wide working bandwidth basically covers the 24.25~29.5GHz 5G millimeter wave frequency band at home and abroad, and has high application value.In order to verify the scanability of the antenna based on the single-mode resonator filter,A 4√ó4 antenna array is designed through the combination of beamforming chips and antennas, and two voltage regulators and 4 beamforming chips are integrated on the board. Each forming chip contains 4 channels, each Each channel is connected to the corresponding antenna unit, and a circle of dummy elements are placed around the active antenna array, and each dummy element is connected to a 50-ohm matching resistor to simulate the surrounding environment of the antenna. Divider, the power divider has a 100 ohm resistor connected to the internal blind hole soldering to achieve good isolation between channels.The antenna test is directly obtained by using a network analyzer. One port is connected to the test antenna, and the other port is connected to the standard horn antenna (21.7~33GHz). The gain of the standard horn antenna in the band is basically stable. When calibrating the phased array beam pointing, 26GHz is used for calibration Center, so the filter characteristics of the antenna under test can be obtained directly.This filtering characteristic combines the filtering characteristics of the antenna itself, the gain unbalance characteristic between different channels of the chip, the gain drop characteristic of the chip on both sides of the frequency band, and the gain drop characteristic caused by the inconsistency of the frequency band of the receiving speaker.The large gain fluctuation in the band is mainly due to the inductive or capacitive output impedance of the chip. When it is connected with the relatively sudden impedance of the filter antenna, it is easy to cause a large impedance mismatch at some frequencies, resulting in a large jitter in the band. . The gain trend of the active filter antenna array is basically the same as that of the chip gain, indicating that the final in-band filtering characteristics of the array mainly depend on the gain flatness of the chip.
summary: A simple and easy-to-integrate millimeter-wave filter antenna and integrated array.
title: Filtenna and filtenna array based on single mode resonator

content:
The first type of antenna is based on short-circuit via loading, which disturbs the current distribution on the surface of the driven patch at the bottom side band, and introduces a filter antenna with additional zero points.Covering the 24.25~29.5GHz 5G millimeter wave broadband communication frequency band.It has the characteristics of broadband, low profile, simple structure, and multiple radiation nulls, and is very suitable for 5G millimeter wave broadband communication applications.
The second filter antenna is based on a single-layer PCB structure that strategically adjusts the position of the feed point to excite a directional pattern of radiation in-band, while the pattern generated out-of-band can well make the The electric fields cancel each other out, basically no radiation is formed to the outside.
summary: A filtenna based on stacked patches and a filtenna based on single-layer PCB.
title: Stacked patches filtenna and single-layer filtenna

content: Abstract: This is a large-scale systematic work to realize a large-scale satellite phased array system with a scale of 32√ó32 array elements. I participated in the design of the antenna module and feed design, the design of the RF transceiver module, and the development of an ultra-low phase noise dielectric oscillator (an oscillator that is super difficult to resonate).The entire system adopts a discrete antenna design, which is convenient for installation and positioning of antenna performance. The entire system works in TDD mode. Each sub-transmission system is responsible for driving four 8-channel beamformers.The entire system can achieve ¬±50¬∞ beam scanning.
summary: The system uses 32√ó32 circularly polarized antennas to achieve a bandwidth of 2GHz and a coverage range of ¬±50¬∞.
title: Large-scale millimeter wave satellite phased array system

content:
Academic is designed to give technical content creators a seamless experience. You can focus on the content and Academic handles the rest.
Highlight your code snippets, take notes on math classes, and draw diagrams from textual representation.
On this page, you’ll find some examples of the types of technical content that can be rendered with Academic.
Examples Code Academic supports a Markdown extension for highlighting code syntax. You can enable this feature by toggling the highlight option in your config/_default/params.toml file.
```python import pandas as pd data = pd.read_csv("data.csv") data.head() ``` renders as
import pandas as pd data = pd.read_csv("data.csv") data.head() Math Academic supports a Markdown extension for $\LaTeX$ math. You can enable this feature by toggling the math option in your config/_default/params.toml file.
To render inline or block math, wrap your LaTeX math with $...$ or $$...$$, respectively.
Example math block:
$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |} {\left \|\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right \|^2}$$ renders as
$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |}{\left |\nabla F(\mathbf{x}{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}{n-1}) \right |^2}$$
Example inline math $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$ renders as $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$.
Example multi-line math using the \\ math linebreak:
$$f(k;p_0^*) = \begin{cases} p_0^* & \text{if }k=1, \\ 1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$ renders as
$$f(k;p_0^) = \begin{cases} p_0^ & \text{if }k=1, \ 1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$
Diagrams Academic supports a Markdown extension for diagrams. You can enable this feature by toggling the diagram option in your config/_default/params.toml file or by adding diagram: true to your page front matter.
An example flowchart:
```mermaid graph TD A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round) B --> C{Decision} C -->|One| D[Result 1] C -->|Two| E[Result 2] ``` renders as
graph TD A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round) B --> C{Decision} C -->|One| D[Result 1] C -->|Two| E[Result 2] An example sequence diagram:
```mermaid sequenceDiagram Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you? loop Healthcheck John->>John: Fight against hypochondria end Note right of John: Rational thoughts! John-->>Alice: Great! John->>Bob: How about you? Bob-->>John: Jolly good! ``` renders as
sequenceDiagram Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you? loop Healthcheck John->>John: Fight against hypochondria end Note right of John: Rational thoughts! John-->>Alice: Great! John->>Bob: How about you? Bob-->>John: Jolly good! An example Gantt diagram:
```mermaid gantt section Section Completed :done, des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08 Active :active, des2, 2014-01-07, 3d Parallel 1 : des3, after des1, 1d Parallel 2 : des4, after des1, 1d Parallel 3 : des5, after des3, 1d Parallel 4 : des6, after des4, 1d ``` renders as
gantt section Section Completed :done, des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08 Active :active, des2, 2014-01-07, 3d Parallel 1 : des3, after des1, 1d Parallel 2 : des4, after des1, 1d Parallel 3 : des5, after des3, 1d Parallel 4 : des6, after des4, 1d An example class diagram:
```mermaid classDiagram Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool <<interface>> Class01 Class09 --> C2 : Where am i? Class09 --* C3 Class09 --|> Class07 Class07 : equals() Class07 : Object[] elementData Class01 : size() Class01 : int chimp Class01 : int gorilla class Class10 { <<service>> int id size() } ``` renders as
classDiagram Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool <<interface>> Class01 Class09 --> C2 : Where am i? Class09 --* C3 Class09 --|> Class07 Class07 : equals() Class07 : Object[] elementData Class01 : size() Class01 : int chimp Class01 : int gorilla class Class10 { <<service>> int id size() } An example state diagram:
```mermaid stateDiagram [*] --> Still Still --> [*] Still --> Moving Moving --> Still Moving --> Crash Crash --> [*] ``` renders as
stateDiagram [*] --> Still Still --> [*] Still --> Moving Moving --> Still Moving --> Crash Crash --> [*] Todo lists You can even write your todo lists in Academic too:
- [x] Write math example - [x] Write diagram example - [ ] Do something else renders as
Write math example Write diagram example Do something else Tables Represent your data in tables:
| First Header | Second Header | | ------------- | ------------- | | Content Cell | Content Cell | | Content Cell | Content Cell | renders as
First Header Second Header Content Cell Content Cell Content Cell Content Cell Did you find this page helpful? Consider sharing it üôå
summary:
Academic is designed to give technical content creators a seamless experience. You can focus on the content and Academic handles the rest.
Highlight your code snippets, take notes on math classes, and draw diagrams from textual representation.
title: Writing technical content in Academic

content: I designed the signal processing board and the power management board for the entire system for a certain radar project, and finally debugged it successfully.
summary: The signal processing and power management board for a radar project was designed using Xilinx FPGA. The final version was debugged successfully.
title: Radar application signal processing and power management board

content:
from IPython.core.display import Image Image('https://www.python.org/static/community_logos/python-logo-master-v3-TM-flattened.png') print("Welcome to Academic!") Welcome to Academic! Install Python and JupyterLab Install Anaconda which includes Python 3 and JupyterLab.
Alternatively, install JupyterLab with pip3 install jupyterlab.
Create or upload a Jupyter notebook Run the following commands in your Terminal, substituting <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER> and <SHORT-POST-TITLE> with the file path to your Academic website folder and a short title for your blog post (use hyphens instead of spaces), respectively:
mkdir -p <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/ cd <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/ jupyter lab index.ipynb The jupyter command above will launch the JupyterLab editor, allowing us to add Academic metadata and write the content.
Edit your post metadata The first cell of your Jupter notebook will contain your post metadata ( front matter).
In Jupter, choose Markdown as the type of the first cell and wrap your Academic metadata in three dashes, indicating that it is YAML front matter:
--- title: My post's title date: 2019-09-01 # Put any other Academic metadata here... --- Edit the metadata of your post, using the documentation as a guide to the available options.
To set a featured image, place an image named featured into your post’s folder.
For other tips, such as using math, see the guide on writing content with Academic.
Convert notebook to Markdown jupyter nbconvert index.ipynb --to markdown --NbConvertApp.output_files_dir=. Example This post was created with Jupyter. The orginal files can be found at https://github.com/gcushen/hugo-academic/tree/master/exampleSite/content/post/jupyter
summary: Learn how to blog in Academic using Jupyter notebooks
title: Display Jupyter Notebooks with Academic

content:
In the wireless synchronization pulse transmission system, the transmitter sends the received synchronization pulse to the receiver wirelessly, and the receiver processes it and outputs it. The specific indicators are as follows:
The transmission delay is not greater than 5 microseconds; The peak transmit power is no more than 1 watt; The transmission distance is not less than 1 km; The size of the signal processing board should be as small as possible, and the power supply voltage should be 12V; The synchronous start pulse detection probability is not less than 99.9%, and the false alarm probability is not more than 1%; It can realize the work of one master and multiple slaves, and the number of slaves is not less than 8.
summary: We have implemented two methods to demodulate a single burst pulse transmitter with multiple receivers in specific scenarios. The first one is based on pulse modulation transceiver, the second one is based on ZYNQ+AD9361 platform
title: Wireless synchronized pulse transmission system

content: We have designed a commercially available ultra-wideband spectrum detection system with a spectrum detection range up to 18GHz. Through the logic control between radio frequency devices, switching between multiple frequency bands is achieved. The entire system is relatively complex and was completed by 8 people, including RF front-end design, signal acquisition and processing, data transmission and storage, and final real-time display on the host computer.I am mainly responsible for the logic control and signal processing part.
summary: We have designed a commercially available ultra-wideband spectrum detection system with a spectrum detection range up to 18GHz.
title: Ultra-wideband spectrum detection system

content:
Based on the Txx millimeter-wave radar platform, systematically analyzed the points formed within the human body by the millimeter-wave MIMO radar with the increase in the number of channels and the change in the number of solution angles under different angles, different distances, and different attitudes of the human body point cloud Quantity Benefit Analysis.
The figure shows only the change in the number of point clouds formed by static and moving human bodies under the current signal processing flow. From the results, it can be seen that moving targets can bring about an increase in the number of detected targets in the Doppler dimension. Provide more target point clouds.
summary: A systematic conclusion analysis about indoor human activity.
title: Benefit Analysis of Multi-Channel Radar Angular Resolution Based on Txx platform

content:
Create a free website with Academic using Markdown, Jupyter, or RStudio. Choose a beautiful color theme and build anything with the Page Builder - over 40 widgets, themes, and language packs included!
Check out the latest demo of what you’ll get in less than 10 minutes, or view the showcase of personal, project, and business sites.
üëâ Get Started üìö View the documentation üí¨ Ask a question on the forum üë• Chat with the community üê¶ Twitter: @source_themes @GeorgeCushen #MadeWithAcademic üí° Request a feature or report a bug ‚¨ÜÔ∏è Updating? View the Update Guide and Release Notes ❤️ Support development of Academic: ‚òïÔ∏è Donate a coffee üíµ Become a backer on Patreon üñºÔ∏è Decorate your laptop or journal with an Academic sticker üëï Wear the T-shirt 👩‍💻 Contribute Academic is mobile first with a responsive design to ensure that your site looks stunning on every device. Key features:
Page builder - Create anything with widgets and elements Edit any type of content - Blog posts, publications, talks, slides, projects, and more! Create content in Markdown, Jupyter, or RStudio Plugin System - Fully customizable color and font themes Display Code and Math - Code highlighting and LaTeX math supported Integrations - Google Analytics, Disqus commenting, Maps, Contact Forms, and more! Beautiful Site - Simple and refreshing one page design Industry-Leading SEO - Help get your website found on search engines and social media Media Galleries - Display your images and videos with captions in a customizable gallery Mobile Friendly - Look amazing on every screen with a mobile friendly version of your site Multi-language - 15+ language packs including English, ‰∏≠Êñá, and Portugu√™s Multi-user - Each author gets their own profile page Privacy Pack - Assists with GDPR Stand Out - Bring your site to life with animation, parallax backgrounds, and scroll effects One-Click Deployment - No servers. No databases. Only files. Themes Academic comes with automatic day (light) and night (dark) mode built-in. Alternatively, visitors can choose their preferred mode - click the sun/moon icon in the top right of the Demo to see it in action! Day/night mode can also be disabled by the site admin in params.toml.
Choose a stunning theme and font for your site. Themes are fully customizable.
Ecosystem Academic Admin: An admin tool to import publications from BibTeX or import assets for an offline site Academic Scripts: Scripts to help migrate content to new versions of Academic Install You can choose from one of the following four methods to install:
one-click install using your web browser (recommended) install on your computer using Git with the Command Prompt/Terminal app install on your computer by downloading the ZIP files install on your computer with RStudio Then personalize and deploy your new site.
Updating View the Update Guide.
Feel free to star the project on Github to help keep track of updates.

summary: Create a beautifully simple website in under 10 minutes.
title: Academic: the website builder for Hugo
